div.head: On cannon-makers
div.ab: The cannon fires five to six hundred pacesat point blank. But not for making battery, for which it is only able to make a good performance at two hundred paces, or three hundred paces at the most, and should not be any farther. Its shot usually weighs 40 lb of the King's standard. There is a fowler, which weighs xxv quintals, which are small, short cannons. It is for fighting the ditch casemates & for battering at close range. It bears large shot of the King's standard like the others, namely of 40 lb. It bears in the breech only the width of two bullets & a quarter of a bullet. The front only bears the width of one bullet & a third of a bullet. Its charge is similar to those of bigger one, namely xx lb. And for this reason, when one wants to try them, one ought not to over-charge it, for this damages the piece. And for the first time & until it has fired five or six pieces shots, it is better not to give its complete charge, for the piece is secured. And the test that one can do is to give it a charge of xx lb. of fine arquebus powder instead of ordinary cannon powder. And four good horses are sufficient to carry it. They are easy, & close up they have as much force as the big ones, particularly for private houses & small towns & fortresses of little importance. They are no more subject to bursting than the others because they are short. For that which gives great strength to the powderm & to the piece the danger of bursting, is the length of the piece, because the powder is burned entirely before exiting, & the its impetuosity is held constrained for longer in a small long piece than a gr short one. The fowler is usually seven to eight pans long. It is true that this is a pan of Montpellier & not a King’s pan, which is not used in the founding of guns for making them good. For the pan of Montpellier being of shorter, the cannons plus proportioned there are shorter also, &compensate in thickness ce the length that they would have by the King’s pan, by which measure they will be found longer. But also they will be thinner. The great cannons The strength of the fowler for making a breach is 80 paces.

left-top
The great cannon, because of the weight of its shot, carries a range of only a thousand or xii hundred paces without landing, &bouncing, usually it bounces iii times.

left-top
The fowlers do not have a large range if not close.

left-middle
One recognizes the good alloy of a piece by seeing it. For if, with the greenness which they expel on the surface, they redden, that is to say that they are composed of a sufficient quantity of rosette. If not, they are only of metal, which shows up whitish. If they themselves do not make this demonstration, scratch & you will see.

left-bottom
The good alloy for pieces is of three parts of rosette & one of the fine metal from a big bell, where there is more rosette than in the metal of small bells. The metal usually costs xv lb & fine rosette xv or xvi.

left-bottom
The pan of Montpellier is equivalent to six poulces of the King's standard, which holds two common.

bottom
It is necessary, for a mounting a piece well, that it be as high at the side of the mouth as at the breech. Otherwise, one does not mount well.
